docs.title: Create Your First Codelab
docs.text: This guide walks you through creating a complete codelab using all core features of Open Codelabs.

docs.title: What is a codelab?
docs.text:
A codelab is a step-by-step learning guide. Each codelab:

  • Consists of multiple steps
  • Uses Markdown content
  • Can include code samples and images
  • Lets attendees proceed at their own pace

docs.title: Access the admin dashboard
docs.text:
1. Log in at http://localhost:5173/login
  2. Open the admin dashboard

docs.title: Create a new codelab
docs.text:
Click "Create New Codelab" and enter the details:

Title: Build a REST API with Rust
Description: Create a RESTful API server using Axum
Author: Jane Doe

Writing a good title

  • Be clear and specific
  • Make the outcome obvious
  • Keep it concise (about 20-50 characters)

docs.title: Step structure design
docs.text:
A good codelab is organized into logical steps:

  1. Overview - introduce what will be learned
  2. Setup - install tools and dependencies
  3. Core concepts - explain the theory
  4. Practice - implement step by step
  5. Testing - verify the result
  6. Wrap-up - recap and next steps

docs.title: Step 1: Overview
docs.text:
# Rust REST API Overview

## What will we build?

In this codelab, you will build a simple TODO REST API using Axum.

## What you will learn

- Axum basics
- RESTful API design principles
- SQLite integration
- Error handling

## Prerequisites

- Rust 1.75+
- Code editor (VS Code recommended)
- Terminal
- Postman or curl

## Estimated time

About 45 minutes

docs.title: Step 2: Environment setup
docs.text:
# Environment Setup

## Create the project

Create a new Rust project:

```bash
cargo new todo-api
cd todo-api

docs.title: Add dependencies
docs.text:
Open Cargo.toml and add the dependencies:

[dependencies]
axum = "0.7"
tokio = { version = "1.0", features = ["full"] }
serde = { version = "1.0", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1.0"
sqlx = { version = "0.8", features = ["runtime-tokio-rustls", "sqlite"] }

docs.title: Project structure
docs.text:
Create the following structure:

todo-api/
|-- Cargo.toml
|-- src/
|   |-- main.rs
|   |-- models.rs
|   `-- handlers.rs
`-- .env

Nice work

The setup is complete. Move to the next step.

### Step 3: Write the data models

```markdown
# Data Models

## Define the Todo struct

Create `src/models.rs` with the following code:

```rust
use serde::{Deserialize, Serialize};

#[derive(Debug, Serialize, Deserialize, Clone)]
pub struct Todo {
    pub id: i64,
    pub title: String,
    pub completed: bool,
}

#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
pub struct CreateTodo {
    pub title: String,
}

#[derive(Debug, Deserialize)]
pub struct UpdateTodo {
    pub title: Option<String>,
    pub completed: Option<bool>,
}

docs.title: The Todo struct
docs.text:
• id: unique identifier
  • title: task title
  • completed: completion flag

docs.title: Serde derives
docs.text:
• #[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)]: JSON serialization/deserialization
  • #[derive(Clone)]: allows cloning

Note

CreateTodo does not include id or completed. These are generated by the server.

## Step 3: Advanced Markdown features

### Code highlighting

You can highlight code blocks for different languages:

````markdown
```rust
fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}

console.log("Hello, world!");


print("Hello, world!")
````

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text:
You can highlight important information:

```markdown

Note

This is general information.

Tip

Useful advice goes here.

Warning

This requires caution.

Danger

This is critical.

Success

Success message.

Info

Additional info.

```

docs.title: Tables
docs.text: markdown | Method | Path | Description | |--------|------|-------------| | GET | /todos | List all todos | | GET | /todos/:id | Get a todo by id | | POST | /todos | Create a todo | | PUT | /todos/:id | Update a todo | | DELETE | /todos/:id | Delete a todo |

docs.title: Links and images
docs.text:
```markdown

Rust Documentation

Upload images in the admin UI to get a URL. ```

docs.title: Lists
docs.text:
```markdown

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Subitem 2.1
  • Subitem 2.2
  • Item 3
  1. First step
  2. Second step
  3. Third step
  • [ ] Todo
  • [x] Done
  • [ ] Remaining ```

docs.title: Upload images
docs.text:
1. Click "Upload Image" in the step editor
  2. Select a file (PNG, JPG, GIF)
  3. Copy the generated URL
  4. Insert into Markdown:

markdown ![Alt text](uploaded_image_url)

docs.title: Resize images
docs.text:
Use HTML to control size:

html <img src="image_url" alt="Description" width="400"> <img src="image_url" alt="Description" style="width: 50%;">

docs.title: Attendee codes
docs.text: An attendee code is generated automatically when you create a codelab. Attendees enter it when joining.

docs.title: Monitor attendees
docs.text:
In the admin dashboard:

  • View the attendee list in real time
  • Track each attendee's progress
  • Manage help requests

docs.title: Handle help requests
docs.text:
When an attendee requests help:

  1. A notification appears
  2. Check which step they are stuck on
  3. Provide help via 1:1 DM
  4. Mark the issue as resolved

docs.title: Global chat
docs.text:
Communicate with all attendees:

[Facilitator]: We will move on in 5 minutes.

docs.title: 1:1 DM
docs.text:
Talk to a specific attendee:

Click the "DM" button next to the attendee name -> Send a private message

docs.title: Export a codelab
docs.text:
1. Select a codelab in the admin dashboard
  2. Click "Export"
  3. Download the ZIP file

ZIP file structure:

codelab_xxx.zip |-- codelab.json # metadata |-- step_1.md # Step 1 content |-- step_2.md # Step 2 content `-- step_3.md # Step 3 content

docs.title: Import a codelab
docs.text:
1. Click "Import"
  2. Select the ZIP file
  3. The codelab and steps are created automatically

Version control

Exporting a codelab makes it easy to version with Git.

docs.title: Step 8: Collect feedback
docs.text:
When attendees complete a codelab, a feedback form is shown automatically:

  • Difficulty: 1-5
  • Satisfaction: 1-5
  • Comments: free-form

Admins can review all feedback in the dashboard.

docs.title: Content authoring
docs.text:
1. Cover only one concept per step
  2. Keep code short and explanations clear
  3. Focus on hands-on practice
  4. Provide verification steps

docs.title: Step length
docs.text:
• Ideal step length: 5-10 minutes
  • Split overly long steps
  • End each step with a summary

docs.title: Visual assets
docs.text:
• Use diagrams for complex ideas
  • Include screenshots for results
  • Visualize architecture with diagrams

docs.title: Error handling
docs.text:
• Include common error cases
  • Provide clear resolutions
  • Add troubleshooting tips

docs.title: Example template
docs.text:
A complete step template:

```markdown

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: In this step, you will learn [learning goal].

docs.title: Concept
docs.text: [Concept explanation]

docs.title: 1. [Sub-step title]
docs.text:
[Explanation]

[language] [code]

docs.title: 2. [Sub-step title]
docs.text:
[Explanation]

[language] [code]

docs.title: Run
docs.text:
bash [command]

Expected output:

[output]

docs.title: Verify
docs.text:
Check the following:

  • [ ] [Check item 1]
  • [ ] [Check item 2]
  • [ ] [Check item 3]

Success

Great job. Move to the next step.

docs.title: Error: [error message]
docs.text:
Cause: [cause]

Fix: [solution]

docs.title: Next step
docs.text: In the next step, you will cover [next topic]. ```

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
You learned how to create your first codelab. Continue with:

  • Public Deployment - expose locally via ngrok/bore/cloudflare
  • API Reference - automation and integrations
  • System Architecture - understand the platform

docs.title: Need help?
docs.text:
• FAQ - common questions
  • GitHub Issues - bug reports
  • Contributing - how to contribute

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide covers different ways to install Open Codelabs.

docs.title: Minimum requirements
docs.text:
• Memory: 2GB RAM
  • Disk: 1GB free space
  • OS: Linux, macOS, Windows (WSL2)

docs.title: Software requirements
docs.text:
Docker (recommended)Local developmentPodman
  • Docker Engine 20.10+
  • Docker Compose v2.0+
  • Rust 1.75+
  • Bun 1.0+
  • SQLite 3.35+
  • Podman 4.0+
  • podman-compose 1.0+

docs.title: Install with Docker
docs.text: Docker is the simplest and recommended approach.

docs.title: 1. Install Docker
docs.text:
LinuxmacOSWindows 
# Ubuntu/Debian
curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sudo sh get-docker.sh

# Install Docker Compose
sudo apt-get install docker-compose-plugin

Download and install Docker Desktop for Mac.

Download and install Docker Desktop for Windows.

WSL2 is recommended.

Docker Desktop includes Docker Compose. On Linux, you may need docker-compose-plugin. Use the docker compose command for modern installations (V1's docker-compose is deprecated).

docs.title: 2. Clone the project
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/JAICHANGPARK/open-codelabs.git
cd open-codelabs

docs.title: 3. Configure environment variables (optional)
docs.text:
You can run with the defaults, but if you want to change admin credentials:

# Edit docker-compose.yml
nano docker-compose.yml

services:
  backend:
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
      - ADMIN_ID=your_admin_id        # change
      - ADMIN_PW=your_secure_password # change

docs.title: 4. Run
docs.text:
docker compose up -d
  • -d: run in the background

docs.title: 5. Check logs
docs.text:
# All services
docker compose logs -f

# Backend only
docker compose logs -f backend

# Frontend only
docker compose logs -f frontend

docs.title: 6. Stop and start
docs.text:
# Stop
docker compose stop

# Start
docker compose start

# Stop and remove containers
docker compose down

# Remove volumes (data loss)
docker compose down -v

docs.title: Install with Podman
docs.text: If you prefer Podman:

docs.title: 1. Install Podman
docs.text:
Fedora/RHELUbuntumacOS 
sudo dnf install podman podman-compose

sudo apt-get install podman podman-compose

brew install podman podman-compose
podman machine init
podman machine start

docs.title: 2. Run
docs.text:
podman-compose up -d

Use podman-compose instead of docker compose for the remaining commands.

docs.title: Local development setup
docs.text: Detailed instructions for local development.

docs.title: 1. Install Rust
docs.text:
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
source $HOME/.cargo/env

# Verify
rustc --version
cargo --version

docs.title: 2. Install Bun
docs.text:
curl -fsSL https://bun.sh/install | bash

# Verify
bun --version

docs.title: 3. Install SQLite
docs.text:
LinuxmacOSWindows 
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install sqlite3 libsqlite3-dev

# Fedora
sudo dnf install sqlite sqlite-devel

brew install sqlite

SQLite is bundled with most Windows installations.

docs.title: 4. Clone and configure
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/JAICHANGPARK/open-codelabs.git
cd open-codelabs

docs.title: 5. Backend setup
docs.text:
cd backend

# Create .env
cat > .env << EOF
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=admin123
RUST_LOG=backend=debug,tower_http=debug
EOF

# Create data directory
mkdir -p data

# Optional: dependency check
cargo check

# Run
cargo run

The backend runs at http://localhost:8080.

docs.title: 6. Frontend setup
docs.text:
In a new terminal:

cd frontend

# Install dependencies
bun install

# Optional env vars
cat > .env << EOF
VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080
EOF

# Run dev server
bun run dev

The frontend runs at http://localhost:5173.

docs.title: Docker production image
docs.text:
# Build production images
docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml build

# Run
docker compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d

docs.title: Backend
docs.text:
cd backend

# Release build
cargo build --release

# Run
./target/release/backend

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text:
cd frontend

# Production build
bun run build

# Preview
bun run preview

docs.title: Install SQLx CLI (for developers)
docs.text:
To manage database migrations:

cargo install sqlx-cli --no-default-features --features sqlite

# Run migrations
cd backend
sqlx migrate run

# Revert a migration
sqlx migrate revert

# Create a new migration
sqlx migrate add <migration_name>

docs.title: Database reset
docs.text:
To reset the database to a clean state:

# Docker
docker compose down -v
rm -rf backend/data/sqlite.db
docker compose up -d

# Local development
rm -rf backend/data/sqlite.db
cargo run

docs.title: Backend
docs.text: Variable Description Default Required DATABASE_URL SQLite database path sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc Yes ADMIN_ID Admin ID admin Yes ADMIN_PW Admin password admin123 Yes RUST_LOG Log level backend=debug,tower_http=debug No

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text: Variable Description Default Required VITE_API_URL Backend API URL http://localhost:8080 No PORT Frontend port 5173 No HOST Bind host 0.0.0.0 No

docs.title: Verification
docs.text: Confirm the installation:

docs.title: 1. Health check
docs.text:
# Backend health check
curl http://localhost:8080/api/codelabs

# Example response
[]

docs.title: 2. Open the frontend
docs.text: Visit http://localhost:5173.

docs.title: 3. Admin login
docs.text:
1. Go to http://localhost:5173/login
  2. Log in with your credentials

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
Installation is complete. Continue with:

  • Create Your First Codelab
  • Public Deployment Guide
  • API Reference

docs.title: Port conflicts
docs.text:
If another process is using the ports:

# Check ports (Linux/macOS)
lsof -i :8080
lsof -i :5173

# Kill the process
kill -9 <PID>

docs.title: Database migration errors
docs.text:
cd backend
rm -rf data/sqlite.db
cargo run

docs.title: Docker build errors
docs.text:
# Rebuild without cache
docker compose build --no-cache

# Cleanup Docker system
docker system prune -a

For more troubleshooting, see the FAQ.

docs.title: Quickstart
docs.text: Use this guide to get Open Codelabs running in about 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Minimum requirements:

  • Docker (recommended), or
  • Bun + Rust for local development

docs.title: Run with Docker (recommended)
docs.text: This is the simplest option. You only need Docker installed.

docs.title: 1. Clone the repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/JAICHANGPARK/open-codelabs.git
cd open-codelabs

docs.title: 2. Start with Docker Compose
docs.text:
docker compose up --build

The first run may take a few minutes while images build.

docs.title: 2-1. Run with Prebuilt Images (Faster Start)
docs.text:
To skip the local build process, you can use the published images from GitHub Container Registry.

# Setup environment variables (Defaults to ghcr.io/jaichangpark/ images)
cp .env.sample .env

# Run using the prebuilt image compose file
docker compose -f docker-compose.images.yml up

docs.title: 3. Open in your browser
docs.text:
Once the build is done:

  • Facilitator (admin): http://localhost:5173/login
  • ID: admin
  • PW: admin
  • Attendee: http://localhost:5173

docs.title: Run locally for development
docs.text: If you are developing, you can run everything locally.

docs.title: Run the backend
docs.text:
cd backend

# Set environment variables
cat > .env << EOF
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=admin123
EOF

# Create database directory
mkdir -p data

# Start the server
cargo run

The backend runs at http://localhost:8080.

docs.title: Run the frontend
docs.text:
In a new terminal:

cd frontend

# Install dependencies
bun install

# Start the dev server
bun run dev

The frontend runs at http://localhost:5173.

docs.title: 1. Log in as admin
docs.text:
1. Go to http://localhost:5173/login
  2. Log in with the default credentials:
  3. ID: admin
  4. PW: admin123

docs.title: 2. Create a codelab
docs.text:
1. Click "Create New Codelab"
  2. Fill in details:
  3. Title: "My First Codelab"
  4. Description: "Build a web server with Rust"
  5. Author: "Jane Doe"
  6. Click "Create"

docs.title: 3. Add steps
docs.text:
Open the newly created codelab card to edit:

  1. Click "Add Step"
  2. Enter step details:
  3. Title: "Project Setup"
  4. Content: Write in Markdown
# Project Setup

Create a new Rust project:

```bash
cargo new my-web-server
cd my-web-server

## Add dependencies

Add these dependencies to Cargo.toml:

[dependencies]
axum = "0.7"
tokio = { version = "1.0", features = ["full"] }
```

  1. Click "Save"

docs.title: 4. Test as an attendee
docs.text:
1. Open a new incognito window (or another browser) and visit http://localhost:5173
  2. Select the codelab
  3. Enter your name and attendee code
  4. Follow the steps

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
You have created your first codelab. Explore the following:

  • Installation Guide - detailed setup options
  • Create Your First Codelab - advanced features
  • Public Deployment - expose locally via ngrok/bore/cloudflare
  • API Reference - automation and integrations

docs.title: Docker containers do not start
docs.text:
# Stop existing containers
docker compose down

# Clean volumes
docker compose down -v

# Restart
docker compose up --build

docs.title: Port is already in use
docs.text:
Update the ports in docker-compose.yml:

services:
  frontend:
    ports:
      - "3000:5173"  # Use 3000 instead of 5173
  backend:
    ports:
      - "3080:8080"  # Use 3080 instead of 8080

docs.title: Database errors
docs.text:
# Reset backend data
rm -rf backend/data/sqlite.db

# Restart
docker compose restart backend

For more troubleshooting, see the FAQ.

docs.title: Open Codelabs AWS (Amazon Web Services) Deployment Guide
docs.text: This document describes several ways to deploy Open Codelabs on AWS infrastructure.

docs.title: AWS deployment options
docs.text: Depending on your architecture, there are three primary approaches.

docs.title: 1. AWS App Runner (recommended, easiest container option)
docs.text: Similar to Google Cloud Run, App Runner is a fully managed service that deploys directly from source or container images. It is the easiest way to run both frontend and backend without managing infrastructure.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
• Frontend: SvelteKit -> App Runner service 1
  • Backend: Rust Axum -> App Runner service 2
  • Database:
  • Simple: SQLite inside the App Runner instance (data resets on restart)
  • Recommended: AWS RDS (PostgreSQL/MySQL)

docs.title: Deployment steps
docs.text:
1. Create ECR repositories 
    aws ecr create-repository --repository-name open-codelabs/backend
aws ecr create-repository --repository-name open-codelabs/frontend
  2. Build and push images 
    # Backend
cd backend
docker build -t [ACCOUNT_ID].dkr.ecr.[REGION].amazonaws.com/open-codelabs/backend:latest .
docker push [ACCOUNT_ID].dkr.ecr.[REGION].amazonaws.com/open-codelabs/backend:latest

# Frontend
cd ../frontend
docker build -t [ACCOUNT_ID].dkr.ecr.[REGION].amazonaws.com/open-codelabs/frontend:latest .
docker push [ACCOUNT_ID].dkr.ecr.[REGION].amazonaws.com/open-codelabs/frontend:latest
  3. Create App Runner services
    • In the AWS Console, open App Runner and click "Create service".
    • Select the images from ECR and configure environment variables.
    • Backend: DATABASE_URL, ADMIN_ID, ADMIN_PW
    • Frontend: VITE_API_URL (backend App Runner URL)

docs.title: 2. AWS EC2 (traditional)
docs.text:
Deploy with Docker Compose on a virtual machine. This can be the cheapest option (especially with Free Tier).

  1. Create an EC2 instance (Amazon Linux 2023 or Ubuntu recommended)
  2. Configure security groups: open ports 80, 443 (HTTPS), 5173 (frontend), 8080 (backend)
  3. Install Docker and Docker Compose
  4. Clone and run 
    git clone https://github.com/JAICHANGPARK/open-codelabs.git
cd open-codelabs
docker compose up -d --build

docs.title: 3. AWS Amplify (frontend only)
docs.text:
Use this if you are running Firebase mode (VITE_USE_FIREBASE=true) or only want to host the frontend on AWS.

  1. Connect the GitHub repo in the Amplify Console
  2. Configure the build settings (SvelteKit is auto-detected)
  3. Add env vars such as VITE_USE_FIREBASE and VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY

docs.title: Database and storage (production)
docs.text: For production, use persistent services for data durability.

docs.title: 1. Database (RDS)
docs.text: Set the backend DATABASE_URL to your RDS instance. - PostgreSQL: postgres://user:password@host:port/dbname - MySQL: mysql://user:password@host:port/dbname

docs.title: 2. Storage (S3)
docs.text: You can use S3 for uploads. - The project currently supports local filesystem or Firebase Storage by default. - For S3, you will need to implement an additional SDK integration. A local volume mount or Firebase mode is recommended for container deployments.

docs.title: Which option should you choose?
docs.text:
Feature App Runner EC2 (Docker) Amplify (Frontend) Difficulty Low Medium Very low Cost Usage based Fixed (instance) Usage based Ops overhead Very low Medium Low Best for Quick prototyping, auto scaling Lowest cost, full control Firebase mode

Conclusion: If you are comfortable with containers, choose App Runner. If cost is the priority, EC2 is a good fit.

docs.title: Related links
docs.text:
• AWS Management Console
  • AWS App Runner Documentation
  • AWS EC2 Documentation

docs.title: Deploy with Docker
docs.text: A complete guide to deploying Open Codelabs with Docker.

docs.title: docker-compose.yml structure
docs.text:
The project's docker-compose.yml file:

services:
  backend:
    build: ./backend
    ports:
      - "8080:8080"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
      - ADMIN_ID=admin
      - ADMIN_PW=admin123
    volumes:
      - ./backend/data:/app/data

  frontend:
    build: ./frontend
    ports:
      - "5173:5173"
    environment:
      - VITE_API_URL=http://backend:8080
      - PORT=5173
      - HOST=0.0.0.0
    depends_on:
      - backend

docs.title: Basic run
docs.text:
# Build and run
docker compose up --build

# Run in the background
docker compose up -d

# View logs
docker compose logs -f

# Stop
docker compose down

Note

Depending on your environment, you may need to use docker compose instead of docker compose.

docs.title: Use GitHub Container Registry images
docs.text: You can use GHCR images instead of building locally. Use docker-compose.images.yml.

docs.title: 1. Prepare environment variables
docs.text:
Create .env in the project root and set the values below.

IMAGE_REGISTRY=ghcr.io
IMAGE_NAMESPACE=open-codelabs
IMAGE_TAG=latest

DATA_VOLUME_PATH=./backend
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=admin123

FRONTEND_PORT=5173
FRONTEND_HOST=0.0.0.0
VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080

docs.title: 2. Run
docs.text:
docker compose -f docker-compose.images.yml up -d

Tip

Set IMAGE_TAG to a release tag instead of latest to pin the version.

docs.title: Key points
docs.text:
• Multi-stage build: minimize final image size
  • Release mode: optimized binary
  • Runtime-only dependencies: no Rust compiler needed
  • Migrations included: auto DB initialization

docs.title: Use .env files
docs.text:
Reference env files from docker-compose.yml:

services:
  backend:
    env_file:
      - backend/.env
    build: ./backend
    # ...

backend/.env:

DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=SecurePassword123!
RUST_LOG=backend=info,tower_http=info

docs.title: Security recommendations
docs.text:
Production security

  • Never use the default password (admin123)
  • Do not commit .env files to Git
  • Use a strong password (20+ characters recommended)
# Generate a strong password
openssl rand -base64 32

docs.title: Volume setup
docs.text: Use volumes to persist database data.

docs.title: SQLite
docs.text:
services:
  backend:
    volumes:
      - ./backend/data:/app/data          # host directory
      - backend_data:/app/data            # Docker volume (recommended)
    # ...

volumes:
  backend_data:

docs.title: PostgreSQL (example)
docs.text:
services:
  db:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    environment:
      - POSTGRES_USER=codelab
      - POSTGRES_PASSWORD=secure_password
      - POSTGRES_DB=open_codelabs
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data

  backend:
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=postgres://codelab:secure_password@db:5432/open_codelabs
    depends_on:
      - db
    # ...

volumes:
  postgres_data:

docs.title: Database backup
docs.text:
# Backup the SQLite database
docker compose exec backend sqlite3 /app/data/sqlite.db ".backup /app/data/backup.db"

# Copy to host
docker cp <container_id>:/app/data/backup.db ./backup.db

docs.title: Automated backup script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# backup.sh

BACKUP_DIR="./backups"
TIMESTAMP=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p $BACKUP_DIR

# Database backup
docker compose exec -T backend sqlite3 /app/data/sqlite.db ".backup /app/data/backup_$TIMESTAMP.db"
docker cp $(docker compose ps -q backend):/app/data/backup_$TIMESTAMP.db $BACKUP_DIR/

echo "Backup created: $BACKUP_DIR/backup_$TIMESTAMP.db"

# Delete backups older than 30 days
find $BACKUP_DIR -name "backup_*.db" -mtime +30 -delete

# Make executable
chmod +x backup.sh

# Schedule daily with cron
0 2 * * * /path/to/backup.sh

docs.title: Nginx proxy
docs.text:
Add nginx to docker-compose.yml:

services:
  nginx:
    image: nginx:alpine
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    volumes:
      - ./nginx.conf:/etc/nginx/nginx.conf:ro
      - ./certs:/etc/nginx/certs:ro
    depends_on:
      - frontend
      - backend

  backend:
    # Replace ports with expose (do not expose publicly)
    expose:
      - "8080"

  frontend:
    expose:
      - "5173"

nginx.conf:

events {
    worker_connections 1024;
}

http {
    upstream frontend {
        server frontend:5173;
    }

    upstream backend {
        server backend:8080;
    }

    server {
        listen 80;
        server_name your-domain.com;

        # Frontend
        location / {
            proxy_pass http://frontend;
            proxy_set_header Host $host;
            proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
            proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
            proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
        }

        # Backend API
        location /api {
            proxy_pass http://backend;
            proxy_set_header Host $host;
            proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        }

        # WebSocket support
        location /api/ws {
            proxy_pass http://backend;
            proxy_http_version 1.1;
            proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
            proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade";
            proxy_set_header Host $host;
        }
    }
}

docs.title: HTTPS/SSL setup
docs.text:
Using Let's Encrypt:

services:
  certbot:
    image: certbot/certbot
    volumes:
      - ./certs:/etc/letsencrypt
      - ./certbot-data:/var/www/certbot
    command: certonly --webroot --webroot-path=/var/www/certbot --email your@email.com --agree-tos --no-eff-email -d your-domain.com

HTTPS nginx configuration:

server {
    listen 443 ssl;
    server_name your-domain.com;

    ssl_certificate /etc/nginx/certs/live/your-domain.com/fullchain.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /etc/nginx/certs/live/your-domain.com/privkey.pem;

    # SSL config
    ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;
    ssl_ciphers HIGH:!aNULL:!MD5;

    # ... other settings
}

# Redirect HTTP to HTTPS
server {
    listen 80;
    server_name your-domain.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

docs.title: Resource limits
docs.text:
services:
  backend:
    deploy:
      resources:
        limits:
          cpus: '1.0'
          memory: 512M
        reservations:
          cpus: '0.5'
          memory: 256M

docs.title: Health checks
docs.text:
services:
  backend:
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8080/api/codelabs"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3
      start_period: 40s

  frontend:
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:5173"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3

docs.title: Auto-restart
docs.text:
services:
  backend:
    restart: unless-stopped

  frontend:
    restart: unless-stopped

docs.title: Basic commands
docs.text:
# Build only
docker compose build

# Build without cache
docker compose build --no-cache

# Run in the background
docker compose up -d

# Run a single service
docker compose up backend

# Scaling (multiple instances)
docker compose up --scale backend=3

# Stop
docker compose stop

# Restart
docker compose restart

# Full cleanup (including volumes)
docker compose down -v

docs.title: Logs and monitoring
docs.text:
# All logs
docker compose logs

# Follow logs
docker compose logs -f

# Specific service logs
docker compose logs -f backend

# Last 100 lines
docker compose logs --tail=100

# Include timestamps
docker compose logs -t

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
# Enter a container
docker compose exec backend sh

# Run a command
docker compose exec backend ls /app/data

# Copy files (container -> host)
docker cp <container_id>:/app/data/sqlite.db ./

# Copy files (host -> container)
docker cp ./config.toml <container_id>:/app/

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
# Remove stopped containers
docker compose rm

# Remove unused images
docker image prune

# Full system cleanup
docker system prune -a

docs.title: Migration error (checksum mismatch)
docs.text:
Recent updates modified migrations for PostgreSQL/MySQL support. Existing SQLite users may see Error: migration ... was previously applied but has been modified. Try one of the following:

  1. Reset the database (recommended): if you do not need the existing data, delete the SQLite file and restart. 
    rm backend/data/sqlite.db
docker compose up --build
  2. Switch to PostgreSQL/MySQL: new databases avoid this problem. See Environment Variables and set DATABASE_URL.

docs.title: Containers keep restarting
docs.text:
# Check logs
docker compose logs backend

# Run manually to see errors
docker compose run backend sh

docs.title: Port conflicts
docs.text:
# Check port usage
sudo lsof -i :8080

# Change port in docker-compose.yml
ports:
  - "8081:8080"  # host:container

docs.title: Low disk space
docs.text:
# Check Docker disk usage
docker system df

# Cleanup
docker system prune -a --volumes

docs.title: Network issues
docs.text:
# Recreate network
docker compose down
docker network prune
docker compose up

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Local development - set up a dev environment
  • Public deployment - expose locally via ngrok/bore/cloudflare
  • Environment variables - detailed configuration

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Docker Compose documentation
  • Docker security best practices
  • Multi-stage builds

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
A detailed guide to all Open Codelabs environment variables.

Where to put env files

  • Docker Compose: repo root .env (referenced by docker-compose.yml)
  • Local dev: backend/.env, frontend/.env

docs.title: DATABASE_URL
docs.text:
Database connection string (SQLite, PostgreSQL, MySQL supported).

SQLite (default): 

DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc

PostgreSQL: 

DATABASE_URL=postgres://user:password@localhost:5432/dbname

MySQL: 

DATABASE_URL=mysql://user:password@localhost:3306/dbname

Format: sqlite:<path>?<options> or <db_type>://<user>:<password>@<host>:<port>/<dbname>

Options: - mode=rwc: read, write, create - mode=ro: read-only - mode=memory: in-memory database

Examples:

# Local development
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc

# Docker
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc

# In-memory (testing)
DATABASE_URL=sqlite::memory:

docs.title: ADMIN_ID
docs.text:
Admin login ID.

ADMIN_ID=admin

Security

Do not use defaults like admin in production.

Recommendations: - 8+ characters - hard to guess - email format is allowed

ADMIN_ID=facilitator_2024
ADMIN_ID=admin@example.com

docs.title: ADMIN_PW
docs.text:
Admin password.

ADMIN_PW=admin123

Required

Change to a strong password in production.

Recommendations: - at least 20 characters - mix of upper/lowercase, numbers, symbols - use a generator

# Generate a strong password
openssl rand -base64 32
# Output: 8vYR3jkLm9nP2qTxWz6CbF4hK7dN5sVuG1aE0iJ3XyO=

ADMIN_PW=8vYR3jkLm9nP2qTxWz6CbF4hK7dN5sVuG1aE0iJ3XyO=

docs.title: AUTH_SECRETS
docs.text:
JWT signing secret list (comma-separated). The first is active; others are kept for verification to allow key rotation. If empty, ADMIN_PW is used as fallback.

AUTH_SECRETS=primary_secret,previous_secret

Legacy

AUTH_SECRET is still read, but new configs should use AUTH_SECRETS.

docs.title: AUTH_ISSUER
docs.text:
JWT issuer claim.

AUTH_ISSUER=open-codelabs

Default: open-codelabs

docs.title: AUTH_AUDIENCE
docs.text:
JWT audience claim.

AUTH_AUDIENCE=open-codelabs

Default: open-codelabs

docs.title: ADMIN_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS
docs.text:
Admin session TTL in seconds.

ADMIN_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS=28800

Default: 28800 (8 hours)

docs.title: ATTENDEE_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS
docs.text:
Attendee session TTL in seconds.

ATTENDEE_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS=43200

Default: 43200 (12 hours)

docs.title: COOKIE_SECURE
docs.text:
Set to true on HTTPS (Secure cookie + __Host- prefix).

COOKIE_SECURE=true

Default: false

docs.title: COOKIE_SAMESITE
docs.text:
Cookie SameSite policy: lax (default), strict, none.

COOKIE_SAMESITE=lax

Note

Using COOKIE_SAMESITE=none requires COOKIE_SECURE=true.

docs.title: TRUST_PROXY
docs.text:
Set to true when running behind a reverse proxy and trusting X-Forwarded-* headers.

TRUST_PROXY=true

Default: false

docs.title: CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS
docs.text:
Allowed origins (comma-separated). If empty, local defaults are allowed.

CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS=http://localhost:5173,http://127.0.0.1:5173

docs.title: RATE_LIMIT_GENERAL_PER_MINUTE
docs.text:
General API requests per minute per IP.

RATE_LIMIT_GENERAL_PER_MINUTE=120

Default: 120

docs.title: RATE_LIMIT_LOGIN_PER_5_MIN
docs.text:
Login requests per 5 minutes per IP.

RATE_LIMIT_LOGIN_PER_5_MIN=20

Default: 20

docs.title: RATE_LIMIT_AI_PER_MINUTE
docs.text:
AI proxy requests per minute per IP.

RATE_LIMIT_AI_PER_MINUTE=30

Default: 30

docs.title: RATE_LIMIT_UPLOAD_PER_MINUTE
docs.text:
Upload and submission POST requests per minute per IP.

RATE_LIMIT_UPLOAD_PER_MINUTE=20

Default: 20

docs.title: CSP_HEADER
docs.text:
Override the Content-Security-Policy header for UI responses. Uses default if empty.

CSP_HEADER=default-src 'self'; img-src 'self' data: blob:

docs.title: HSTS_HEADER
docs.text:
Override the Strict-Transport-Security header. Applied only on HTTPS.

HSTS_HEADER=max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains; preload

docs.title: ALLOWED_GEMINI_MODELS
docs.text:
Allowed Gemini model IDs (comma-separated). Requests not in the list are rejected.

ALLOWED_GEMINI_MODELS=gemini-3-flash-preview,gemini-1.5-pro

docs.title: GEMINI_API_KEY
docs.text:
Default Gemini API key when no admin key is stored.

GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here

docs.title: RUST_LOG
docs.text:
Log level settings.

RUST_LOG=backend=debug,tower_http=debug

Levels: error, warn, info, debug, trace

Per-module settings:

# Global debug
RUST_LOG=debug

# Per module
RUST_LOG=backend=debug,sqlx=info,tower_http=warn

# Specific handler only
RUST_LOG=backend::handlers::codelabs=trace

# Production
RUST_LOG=backend=info,tower_http=info

docs.title: PORT (backend)
docs.text:
Backend API server port.

# Default: 8080
PORT=8080

# Custom port
PORT=3000

To use in code, update main.rs:

let port = std::env::var("PORT")
    .unwrap_or_else(|_| "8080".to_string())
    .parse::<u16>()
    .expect("PORT must be a valid number");

let addr = SocketAddr::from(([0, 0, 0, 0], port));

docs.title: VITE_API_URL
docs.text:
Backend API URL.

VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080

Common environments:

# Local development
VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080

# Docker Compose (internal network)
VITE_API_URL=http://backend:8080

# Production
VITE_API_URL=https://api.example.com

# ngrok
VITE_API_URL=https://abc123.ngrok-free.app

# Cloudflare Tunnel
VITE_API_URL=https://abc123.trycloudflare.com

Vite env vars

  • Only variables starting with VITE_ are exposed to the client
  • Injected at build time
  • Do not include secrets

docs.title: VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD
docs.text:
Password used to encrypt the Gemini API key in the browser. It must match backend ADMIN_PW for decryption. If empty, the UI prompts for it.

VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD=your_admin_pw

docs.title: FRONTEND_PORT
docs.text:
Frontend container port (host mapping) in Docker Compose, passed to PORT.

FRONTEND_PORT=5173

docs.title: FRONTEND_HOST
docs.text:
Frontend bind host in Docker Compose, passed to HOST.

FRONTEND_HOST=0.0.0.0

docs.title: PORT
docs.text:
Frontend server port.

PORT=5173  # default

In Docker Compose, FRONTEND_PORT is passed to PORT.

docs.title: HOST
docs.text:
Bind host.

HOST=0.0.0.0  # all interfaces
HOST=127.0.0.1  # localhost only

In Docker Compose, FRONTEND_HOST is passed to HOST.

docs.title: Local development
docs.text:
backend/.env:

DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=admin123
AUTH_SECRETS=change_me_primary,change_me_old
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_gemini_api_key_here
RUST_LOG=backend=debug,tower_http=debug,sqlx=info

frontend/.env:

VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080
VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD=admin123

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
The repo root .env is injected into docker-compose.yml.

.env (repo root):

DATA_VOLUME_PATH=~/open-codelabs
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=YourSecurePassword123!
AUTH_SECRETS=change_me_primary,change_me_old
VITE_API_URL=http://localhost:8080
VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD=YourSecurePassword123!
FRONTEND_PORT=5173
FRONTEND_HOST=0.0.0.0

docker-compose.yml (excerpt):

services:
  backend:
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=${DATABASE_URL}
      - ADMIN_ID=${ADMIN_ID}
      - ADMIN_PW=${ADMIN_PW}
    volumes:
      - ${DATA_VOLUME_PATH}/data:/app/data
      - ${DATA_VOLUME_PATH}/uploads:/app/static/uploads

  frontend:
    environment:
      - VITE_API_URL=${VITE_API_URL}
      - VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD=${ADMIN_PW}
      - PORT=${FRONTEND_PORT}
      - HOST=${FRONTEND_HOST}

The default docker-compose.yml passes ADMIN_PW into VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD. If you want a different value, update frontend.environment.

If needed, add backend variables (AUTH_, COOKIE_, CORS_, RATE_LIMIT_, CSP_HEADER, HSTS_HEADER, ALLOWED_GEMINI_MODELS, etc.) to backend.environment.

You can also add env_file entries to inject backend/.env and frontend/.env directly:

services:
  backend:
    env_file:
      - backend/.env

  frontend:
    env_file:
      - frontend/.env

docs.title: Production
docs.text:
backend/.env.production:

DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=${ADMIN_ID}  # injected externally
ADMIN_PW=${ADMIN_PW}  # injected externally
AUTH_SECRETS=${AUTH_SECRETS}
COOKIE_SECURE=true
TRUST_PROXY=true
RUST_LOG=backend=info,tower_http=warn

frontend/.env.production:

VITE_API_URL=https://api.yourdomain.com
VITE_ADMIN_ENCRYPTION_PASSWORD=${ADMIN_PW}

Secret management:

# .env.local (do not commit)
ADMIN_ID=your_real_admin_id
ADMIN_PW=your_real_secure_password

# Inject via env
export ADMIN_ID="your_real_admin_id"
export ADMIN_PW="your_real_secure_password"
docker compose up

docs.title: Validate on backend startup
docs.text:
Add to main.rs:

fn validate_env() -> anyhow::Result<()> {
    let required = vec!["DATABASE_URL", "ADMIN_ID", "ADMIN_PW"];

    for var in required {
        std::env::var(var)
            .map_err(|_| anyhow::anyhow!("{} must be set", var))?;
    }

    // Check password strength
    let pw = std::env::var("ADMIN_PW")?;
    if pw.len() < 12 {
        tracing::warn!("ADMIN_PW is too short! Use at least 12 characters.");
    }

    Ok(())
}

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> anyhow::Result<()> {
    dotenvy::dotenv().ok();
    validate_env()?;

    // ...
}

docs.title: Validate with a script
docs.text:
check-env.sh:

#!/bin/bash

required_backend=("DATABASE_URL" "ADMIN_ID" "ADMIN_PW")
required_frontend=("VITE_API_URL")

echo "Checking backend environment..."
for var in "${required_backend[@]}"; do
    if [ -z "${!var}" ]; then
        echo "$var is not set"
        exit 1
    else
        echo "$var is set"
    fi
done

echo "Checking frontend environment..."
for var in "${required_frontend[@]}"; do
    if [ -z "${!var}" ]; then
        echo "$var is not set"
        exit 1
    else
        echo "$var is set"
    fi
done

echo "All required environment variables are set"

chmod +x check-env.sh
source backend/.env && source frontend/.env && ./check-env.sh

docs.title: 1. Protect .env files
docs.text:
.gitignore:

# Environment variables
.env
.env.local
.env.production
.env.*.local
backend/.env
frontend/.env

# Databases
*.db
*.db-*

docs.title: 2. Provide example files
docs.text:
.env.example:

# Backend Configuration
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=your_admin_id_here
ADMIN_PW=your_secure_password_here
RUST_LOG=backend=info,tower_http=info

# Instructions:
# 1. Copy this file to .env
# 2. Replace placeholder values
# 3. Never commit .env to version control

Usage:

cp .env.example .env
nano .env  # edit values

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
name: Deploy

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Deploy with secrets
        env:
          ADMIN_ID: ${{ secrets.ADMIN_ID }}
          ADMIN_PW: ${{ secrets.ADMIN_PW }}
        run: |
          echo "DATABASE_URL=sqlite:/app/data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc" > backend/.env
          echo "ADMIN_ID=$ADMIN_ID" >> backend/.env
          echo "ADMIN_PW=$ADMIN_PW" >> backend/.env
          docker compose up -d

Set these in Repository Settings -> Secrets.

docs.title: 4. Production password policy
docs.text:
# Minimum requirement validation
validate_password() {
    local pw=$1
    local len=${#pw}

    if [ $len -lt 20 ]; then
        echo "Password too short (minimum 20 characters)"
        return 1
    fi

    if ! [[ "$pw" =~ [A-Z] ]]; then
        echo "Password must contain uppercase letters"
        return 1
    fi

    if ! [[ "$pw" =~ [a-z] ]]; then
        echo "Password must contain lowercase letters"
        return 1
    fi

    if ! [[ "$pw" =~ [0-9] ]]; then
        echo "Password must contain numbers"
        return 1
    fi

    echo "Password meets requirements"
    return 0
}

validate_password "$ADMIN_PW"

docs.title: Check current settings
docs.text:
# Backend
cd backend
cargo run --bin print-env

# Or directly
env | grep -E '(DATABASE_URL|ADMIN_ID|RUST_LOG)'

# Frontend
cd frontend
bun run dev --mode development

docs.title: Log environment variables
docs.text:
Backend main.rs:

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> anyhow::Result<()> {
    dotenvy::dotenv().ok();

    tracing::info!("DATABASE_URL: {}", std::env::var("DATABASE_URL")?);
    tracing::info!("ADMIN_ID: {}", std::env::var("ADMIN_ID")?);
    tracing::info!("ADMIN_PW: ********");  // do not log passwords
    tracing::info!("RUST_LOG: {:?}", std::env::var("RUST_LOG").ok());

    // ...
}

Note

Do not print sensitive values (passwords, API keys) in logs.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• Docker deployment - production deployment with Docker
  • Security guide - operational security checklist
  • FAQ - common questions

docs.title: Open Codelabs Firebase Deployment Guide
docs.text: This document explains how to deploy Open Codelabs with Firebase (Hosting + Firestore + Realtime Database) for users who do not want to run the Rust/SQLite server.

docs.title: 1. Prepare a Firebase project
docs.text:
1. Create a new project in the Firebase Console.
  2. Enable Firestore Database (production mode or test mode).
  3. Enable Realtime Database (for chat and progress sync).
  4. Enable Firebase Storage (for image uploads).
  5. Enable Google sign-in in Firebase Authentication.
  6. In Project Settings, add a Web App and note the Firebase SDK config.

docs.title: 2. Configure the frontend
docs.text:
Add the following to frontend/.env.

# Enable Firebase mode
VITE_USE_FIREBASE=true

# Admin credentials (Firebase mode only, fallback)
VITE_ADMIN_ID=admin
VITE_ADMIN_PW=admin123

# Firebase SDK config
VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY=your_api_key
VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN=your_project.firebaseapp.com
VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID=your_project_id
VITE_FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET=your_project.appspot.com
VITE_FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID=your_sender_id
VITE_FIREBASE_APP_ID=your_app_id
VITE_FIREBASE_DATABASE_URL=https://your_project.firebaseio.com

docs.title: 3. Switch the SvelteKit adapter
docs.text:
To deploy as a static site on Firebase Hosting, use adapter-static.

  1. Install the adapter in the frontend directory: 
    cd frontend
bun add -D @sveltejs/adapter-static
  2. Update svelte.config.js: 
    import adapter from '@sveltejs/adapter-static';
// ...
  3. Configure CSR and prerendering in src/routes/+layout.ts if needed (it may already be set).

docs.title: 4. Security rules and indexes
docs.text: These files in the project root are applied during deployment: - firestore.rules: Firestore access rules - database.rules.json: Realtime Database rules (chat, etc.) - storage.rules: Storage upload rules - firestore.indexes.json: indexes for efficient queries

docs.title: 5. Deploy
docs.text:
1. Install and log in to the Firebase CLI: 
    npm install -g firebase-tools
firebase login
  2. Build the project: 
    cd frontend
bun run build
  3. Deploy to Firebase: 
    cd ..
firebase deploy

docs.title: Key features and notes
docs.text:
• Google sign-in: Firebase Auth supports Google login, and signed-in users can manage or review their codelabs.
  • Realtime features: Realtime Database is used for chat, help requests, and progress sharing.
  • Data storage: codelab metadata and steps are stored in Firestore.
  • Limitations: In Firebase mode, ZIP import/export is not supported.

docs.title: Related links
docs.text:
• Firebase Console
  • Firebase Hosting docs

docs.title: Open Codelabs GCP (Google Cloud Platform) Deployment Guide
docs.text: This document describes several ways to deploy Open Codelabs on GCP.

docs.title: GCP deployment options
docs.text: Depending on your architecture, there are three primary approaches.

docs.title: 1. Firebase (recommended, easiest serverless option)
docs.text:
Firebase is a developer-friendly suite of GCP services. The project already supports Firebase mode, so you can deploy without managing servers.

  • Hosting: frontend (SvelteKit)
  • Firestore: codelab data and user info
  • Realtime Database: chat and progress sharing
  • Storage: image uploads
  • Auth: Google login

See the detailed guide: DEPLOY_FIREBASE.md.

docs.title: 2. Cloud Run (container-based)
docs.text: Build the backend (Rust) and frontend as containers and deploy them separately. This is suitable when you want more control over the infrastructure.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
• Frontend: SvelteKit (Node.js/Bun) -> Cloud Run service 1
  • Backend: Rust Axum -> Cloud Run service 2
  • Database:
  • Simple: SQLite on a Cloud Run local volume. Note: Cloud Run is stateless, so the SQLite file resets on restart. For non-temporary usage, use the recommended option below.
  • Recommended: switch to Cloud SQL (PostgreSQL/MySQL) or use Firebase mode.

docs.title: Deployment steps
docs.text:
1. Configure the GCP project and login 

gcloud auth login
gcloud config set project [YOUR_PROJECT_ID]

2. Create Artifact Registry 

gcloud artifacts repositories create open-codelabs \
    --repository-format=docker --location=asia-northeast3

3. Build and push images 

# Backend build
cd backend
gcloud builds submit --tag asia-northeast3-docker.pkg.dev/[PROJECT_ID]/open-codelabs/backend:latest .

# Frontend build
cd ../frontend
gcloud builds submit --tag asia-northeast3-docker.pkg.dev/[PROJECT_ID]/open-codelabs/frontend:latest .

4. Deploy Cloud Run services - Backend: 

gcloud run deploy backend \
    --image asia-northeast3-docker.pkg.dev/[PROJECT_ID]/open-codelabs/backend:latest \
    --platform managed --region asia-northeast3 --allow-unauthenticated \
    --set-env-vars "DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc,ADMIN_ID=admin,ADMIN_PW=admin123"
- Frontend: 
gcloud run deploy frontend \
    --image asia-northeast3-docker.pkg.dev/[PROJECT_ID]/open-codelabs/frontend:latest \
    --platform managed --region asia-northeast3 --allow-unauthenticated \
    --set-env-vars "VITE_API_URL=[BACKEND_SERVICE_URL]"

docs.title: 3. Compute Engine (traditional VM)
docs.text:
Deploy with Docker Compose on a GCP VM.

  1. Create a GCE instance (Debian or Ubuntu)
  2. Install Docker and Docker Compose
  3. Clone the repo and run docker-compose.yml 
    docker compose up -d --build

docs.title: Which option should you choose?
docs.text:
Feature Firebase (Serverless) Cloud Run (Containers) Compute Engine (VM) Difficulty Very low Medium Medium Cost Usage based (generous free tier) Usage based Fixed (instance time) Realtime Firebase RTDB (very stable) WebSocket (sticky session required) WebSocket (full control) Maintenance Almost none Low High

Conclusion: For a first deployment or small workshops, Firebase is strongly recommended. If you need custom server behavior or want to go deeper with GCP, consider Cloud Run.

docs.title: Related links
docs.text:
• GCP Console
  • Firebase Console
  • Cloud Run Documentation

docs.title: GitHub Pages Deployment Guide
docs.text: This document explains how to deploy MkDocs documentation to GitHub Pages automatically.

docs.title: Step 1: Enable GitHub Pages
docs.text:
1. Go to the GitHub repository
  2. Click Settings
  3. Click Pages in the left menu
  4. In Source:
  5. Select GitHub Actions

docs.title: Step 2: Verify workflow files
docs.text:
These files should already exist:

.github/workflows/
|-- docs.yml              # auto deploy workflow
`-- docs-pr-preview.yml   # PR build check

docs.title: 2. Push to the repository
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "docs: setup MkDocs with GitHub Pages deployment"
git push origin main

docs.title: 3. Verify deployment
docs.text:
1. Open the Actions tab
  2. Find the "Deploy MkDocs to GitHub Pages" workflow
  3. After the build completes (1-2 minutes):
  4. Confirm success
  5. Check the URL in Settings > Pages

Deployed URL: 

https://<username>.github.io/<repository-name>/

Example: 

https://yourusername.github.io/open-codelabs/

docs.title: docs.yml (auto deploy)
docs.text:
Triggers: - Push to main - Changes to docs/, mkdocs.yml, requirements.txt - Manual run (workflow_dispatch)

Steps: 1. Checkout 2. Install Python 3. Install dependencies (requirements.txt) 4. Build MkDocs (mkdocs build) 5. Deploy to GitHub Pages

docs.title: docs-pr-preview.yml (PR checks)
docs.text:
Triggers: - Pull request opened - Documentation-related files changed

Steps: 1. Build MkDocs 2. Comment on PR if build succeeds 3. Show errors if build fails

docs.title: Custom domain
docs.text:
1. Create CNAME in docs/:
echo "docs.yourdomain.com" > docs/CNAME
  1. Add site_url in mkdocs.yml:
site_url: https://docs.yourdomain.com/
  1. DNS setup:
  2. CNAME record: docs -> <username>.github.io

docs.title: Change base URL
docs.text:
If the repo name is not open-codelabs, update mkdocs.yml:

site_url: https://<username>.github.io/<your-repo-name>/

docs.title: Deployment fails
docs.text:
Cause 1: GitHub Pages disabled

Fix: 1. Settings > Pages 2. Set Source to "GitHub Actions"

Cause 2: Permissions

Fix: 1. Settings > Actions > General 2. "Workflow permissions" 3. Select "Read and write permissions" 4. Enable "Allow GitHub Actions to create and approve pull requests"

Cause 3: Build errors

Fix: 

# Test locally
mkdocs build --strict

# Fix the errors

docs.title: 404 on pages
docs.text:
Cause: incorrect base URL.

Fix:

Check site_url in mkdocs.yml:

# Correct format
site_url: https://yourusername.github.io/open-codelabs/

# Or custom domain
site_url: https://docs.yourdomain.com/

docs.title: CSS/JS not loading
docs.text:
Cause: relative path issue.

Fix:

Add in mkdocs.yml:

use_directory_urls: true

docs.title: Images do not render
docs.text:
Cause: incorrect image paths.

Fix:

Reference images like this:

![Image](../assets/image.png)

# Or absolute path
![Image](/assets/image.png)

Store images in docs/assets/.

docs.title: Workflow status badge
docs.text:
Add a badge to README.md:

[![Documentation](https://github.com/<username>/<repo>/actions/workflows/docs.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/<username>/<repo>/actions/workflows/docs.yml)

docs.title: Manual deployment
docs.text: You can also deploy manually.

docs.title: Option 1: Run from GitHub Actions
docs.text:
1. Open Actions
  2. Select "Deploy MkDocs to GitHub Pages"
  3. Click "Run workflow"
  4. Confirm "Run workflow"

docs.title: Option 2: Deploy locally
docs.text:
# Use mkdocs-ghpages plugin
pip install mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin

# Deploy to gh-pages branch
mkdocs gh-deploy --force

# Deploy with message
mkdocs gh-deploy -m "docs: update documentation"

Note

Local deployment can conflict with GitHub Actions. Use GitHub Actions when possible.

docs.title: Deployment history
docs.text:
1. Open Actions
  2. Select "Deploy MkDocs to GitHub Pages"
  3. Review each run
  4. Download logs and artifacts

docs.title: 1. Branch strategy
docs.text:
# Work on a feature branch
git checkout -b docs/update-installation-guide

# Edit docs
vim docs/getting-started/installation.md

# Commit
git commit -m "docs: update installation guide for M1 Mac"

# Open a PR
git push origin docs/update-installation-guide

docs.title: 2. Commit messages
docs.text:
# Good examples
docs: add architecture documentation
docs: fix typo in API reference
docs: update deployment guide with GitHub Actions

# Bad examples
Update docs
Fix
Docs update

docs.title: 3. PR review
docs.text:
• Open a PR for documentation changes
  • Ensure the build checks pass
  • Review content
  • Merge and auto-deploy

docs.title: Use secrets (if needed)
docs.text:
Store sensitive data in GitHub Secrets:

  1. Settings > Secrets and variables > Actions
  2. "New repository secret"
  3. Use in workflow:
- name: Deploy
  env:
    API_KEY: ${{ secrets.API_KEY }}
  run: mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text:
• GitHub Pages docs
  • GitHub Actions docs
  • MkDocs deployment guide
  • Material for MkDocs setup

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
Before deployment:

  • [ ] GitHub Pages set to "GitHub Actions"
  • [ ] site_url is correct in mkdocs.yml
  • [ ] requirements.txt includes all dependencies
  • [ ] mkdocs build --strict passes locally
  • [ ] .github/workflows/docs.yml exists
  • [ ] Changes pushed to main

After deployment:

  • [ ] Workflow success in Actions
  • [ ] GitHub Pages URL accessible
  • [ ] All pages render correctly
  • [ ] Navigation works
  • [ ] Search works
  • [ ] Mobile rendering works

docs.title: Done
docs.text:
The docs are now auto-deployed:

  1. Push changes to main
  2. GitHub Actions builds and deploys
  3. Changes appear in 1-2 minutes

Docs URL: https://<username>.github.io/<repository>/

docs.title: Local Development Environment
docs.text: A setup guide for local development.

docs.title: Install required tools
docs.text:
macOSLinux (Ubuntu/Debian)Windows (WSL2) 
# Install with Homebrew
brew install rust bun sqlite

# Check versions
rustc --version
cargo --version
bun --version

# Rust
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
source $HOME/.cargo/env

# Bun
curl -fsSL https://bun.sh/install | bash

# SQLite
sudo apt-get install sqlite3 libsqlite3-dev

Follow the Linux installation steps inside WSL2 Ubuntu.

docs.title: VS Code (recommended)
docs.text:
Recommended extensions:

{
  "recommendations": [
    "rust-lang.rust-analyzer",
    "svelte.svelte-vscode",
    "oven.bun-vscode",
    "tamasfe.even-better-toml",
    "serayuzgur.crates"
  ]
}

.vscode/settings.json:

{
  "rust-analyzer.checkOnSave.command": "clippy",
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "[rust]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "rust-lang.rust-analyzer"
  },
  "[svelte]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "svelte.svelte-vscode"
  },
  "[typescript]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode"
  }
}

docs.title: IntelliJ IDEA / RustRover
docs.text:
Plugins:

  • Rust
  • Svelte
  • Bun
  • TOML

docs.title: Project structure
docs.text:
backend/
|-- Cargo.toml              # dependencies
|-- .env                    # environment variables

docs.title: Run the dev server
docs.text:
cd backend

# Set env vars
cat > .env << EOF
DATABASE_URL=sqlite:data/sqlite.db?mode=rwc
ADMIN_ID=admin
ADMIN_PW=admin123
RUST_LOG=backend=debug,tower_http=debug,sqlx=info
EOF

# Create data directory
mkdir -p data

# Check dependencies
cargo check

# Run in dev mode
cargo run

# Or watch mode (auto restart on changes)
cargo install cargo-watch
cargo watch -x run

#!/bin/bash

# Create tmux session
tmux new-session -d -s codelabs

# Backend window
tmux rename-window -t codelabs:0 'backend'
tmux send-keys -t codelabs:0 'cd backend && cargo watch -x run' C-m

# Frontend window

docs.title: Automation with Make
docs.text:
Makefile:

.PHONY: dev backend frontend check test clean

# Start full dev environment
dev:
    @echo "Starting development environment..."
    @make -j2 backend frontend

# Run backend
backend:
    cd backend && cargo watch -x run

# Run frontend
frontend:
    cd frontend && bun run dev

# Code checks
check:
    cd backend && cargo clippy && cargo fmt --check
    cd frontend && bun run check

# Tests
test:
    cd backend && cargo test
    cd frontend && bun test

# Build
build:
    cd backend && cargo build --release
    cd frontend && bun run build

# Clean
clean:
    cd backend && cargo clean
    cd frontend && rm -rf node_modules .svelte-kit build

Usage:

make dev      # start dev environment
make check    # code checks
make test     # run tests
make build    # production build
make clean    # cleanup

        },
        watch: {

docs.title: Public deployment (ngrok/bore/cloudflare)
docs.text: How to expose your local server for workshops or events.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Open Codelabs provides a run-public.sh script to expose your local server easily:

  • ngrok: the most popular tunneling service
  • bore: a Rust-based open-source alternative
  • Cloudflare Tunnel: provides a free quick tunnel (cloudflared)

docs.title: 1. Install ngrok
docs.text:
macOSLinuxWindows 
brew install ngrok

# Snap
snap install ngrok

# Or download directly
wget https://bin.equinox.io/c/bNyj1mQVY4c/ngrok-v3-stable-linux-amd64.tgz
tar xvzf ngrok-v3-stable-linux-amd64.tgz
sudo mv ngrok /usr/local/bin

Install from the ngrok download page.

docs.title: 2. ngrok auth (optional)
docs.text:
You can use the free plan, but creating an account unlocks more features:

# Sign up at ngrok.com and copy the token
ngrok config add-authtoken <your_token>

docs.title: 3. Run
docs.text:
chmod +x run-public.sh
./run-public.sh --ngrok

Example output:

Starting Open-Codelabs: Hands-on System using docker...
Containers are up!
Starting ngrok tunnel on port 5173...
------------------------------------------------
Your Codelab is now PUBLIC!
Admin Dashboard: https://abc123.ngrok-free.app/admin
Attendee Entry:  https://abc123.ngrok-free.app
------------------------------------------------

docs.title: 4. Generate a QR code
docs.text:
Create a QR code so participants can connect easily:

# Install qrencode
brew install qrencode  # macOS
apt-get install qrencode  # Linux

# Generate a QR code
echo "https://abc123.ngrok-free.app" | qrencode -t UTF8

# Or save as an image
echo "https://abc123.ngrok-free.app" | qrencode -o qr.png

The admin dashboard also shows a QR code automatically.

docs.title: Use bore
docs.text: bore is an open-source alternative and can be self-hosted.

docs.title: 1. Install bore
docs.text: cargo install bore-cli

docs.title: 2. Run
docs.text:
./run-public.sh --bore

bore uses bore.pub by default.

docs.title: 3. Custom bore server
docs.text:
Run your own server:

# Start the server
bore server --secret <your_secret>

# Connect the client
bore local 5173 --to your-server.com --port 80 --secret <your_secret>

docs.title: Use Cloudflare Tunnel
docs.text: Cloudflare Tunnel provides a free quick tunnel and generates a trycloudflare.com URL automatically.

docs.title: 1. Install cloudflared
docs.text:
macOSLinuxWindows 
brew install cloudflare/cloudflare/cloudflared

Install from the Cloudflare download guide.

Install from the Cloudflare download guide.

docs.title: 2. Run
docs.text:
./run-public.sh --cloudflare

The public URL is printed in the cloudflared logs.

docs.title: Script content
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

set -e

# Default values
TUNNEL_TYPE="ngrok"
CONTAINER_ENGINE="docker"
PORT="${PORT:-5173}"

# Check for podman
if command -v podman-compose &> /dev/null; then
    CONTAINER_ENGINE="podman"
elif command -v docker compose &> /dev/null; then
    CONTAINER_ENGINE="docker"
else
    echo "No container engine found!"
    exit 1
fi

# Parse arguments
while [[ "$#" -gt 0 ]]; do
    case $1 in
        --bore) TUNNEL_TYPE="bore"; shift ;;
        --cloudflare) TUNNEL_TYPE="cloudflare"; shift ;;
        --ngrok) TUNNEL_TYPE="ngrok"; shift ;;
        *) echo "Unknown parameter: $1"; exit 1 ;;
    esac
done

echo "Starting Open-Codelabs Hands-on System using $CONTAINER_ENGINE..."

# Start containers in background
if [ "$CONTAINER_ENGINE" == "podman" ]; then
    podman-compose up -d
else
    docker compose up -d
fi

echo "Containers are up!"

if [ "$TUNNEL_TYPE" == "ngrok" ]; then
    echo "Starting ngrok tunnel on port $PORT..."
    ngrok http "$PORT" --log=stdout &
    sleep 5
    PUBLIC_URL=$(curl -s http://localhost:4040/api/tunnels | grep -o 'https://[^\"]*.ngrok-free.app' | head -n 1)
elif [ "$TUNNEL_TYPE" == "bore" ]; then
    echo "Starting bore tunnel on port $PORT..."
    bore local "$PORT" --to bore.pub &
    sleep 5
    echo "Please check the bore output above for your public URL."
    PUBLIC_URL="[Check Bore Output]"
elif [ "$TUNNEL_TYPE" == "cloudflare" ]; then
    echo "Starting Cloudflare tunnel on port $PORT..."
    cloudflared tunnel --url "http://localhost:$PORT" --no-autoupdate &
    sleep 5
    echo "Please check the cloudflared output above for your public URL."
    PUBLIC_URL="[Check Cloudflared Output]"
fi

if [ -z "$PUBLIC_URL" ] || [ "$PUBLIC_URL" == "[Check Bore Output]" ] || [ "$PUBLIC_URL" == "[Check Cloudflared Output]" ]; then
    if [ "$TUNNEL_TYPE" == "ngrok" ]; then
        echo "Failed to get ngrok URL. Is ngrok running?"
    fi
else
    echo "------------------------------------------------"
    echo "Your Codelab is now PUBLIC!"
    echo "Admin Dashboard: $PUBLIC_URL/admin"
    echo "Attendee Entry:  $PUBLIC_URL"
    echo "------------------------------------------------"
fi

# Keep script running
wait

[Unit]

[Service]
Type=simple
User=your_user
WorkingDirectory=/path/to/open-codelabs
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/ngrok http 5173

[Install]

docs.title: Security Guide
docs.text: This document provides practical guidance for running Open Codelabs safely in a self-hosted environment.

docs.title: Quick checklist
docs.text:
• Change ADMIN_PW to a strong password and rotate it regularly.
  • Set AUTH_SECRETS to separate signing keys and allow rotation.
  • Enable COOKIE_SECURE=true when using HTTPS.
  • Use TRUST_PROXY=true only when running behind a proxy.
  • Restrict CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS to real frontend domains.
  • Tune RATE_LIMIT_* values for your environment.
  • Minimize permissions for upload paths and database files.

docs.title: Auth, sessions, and CSRF
docs.text:
• Admin and attendee auth uses session-cookie JWTs.
  • On login or attendee registration, a session cookie (oc_session) and CSRF cookie (oc_csrf) are issued.
  • With a session, POST/PUT/DELETE requests must include the oc_csrf value in the X-CSRF-Token header.
  • With HTTPS and COOKIE_SECURE=true, cookies use the __Host- prefix.

Related environment variables:

AUTH_SECRETS=secret1,secret2
ADMIN_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS=28800
ATTENDEE_SESSION_TTL_SECONDS=43200
COOKIE_SECURE=true
COOKIE_SAMESITE=lax

docs.title: Network and HTTPS
docs.text:
• Production must be protected with HTTPS.
  • Set TRUST_PROXY=true only when running behind a reverse proxy (Nginx/Traefik/Caddy).
  • Ensure the proxy forwards x-forwarded-proto correctly.

Related environment variables:

TRUST_PROXY=true
CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS=https://codelabs.example.com

docs.title: Security headers
docs.text:
Default CSP/HSTS headers are included in code and can be overridden via environment variables.

CSP_HEADER=default-src 'self'; ...
HSTS_HEADER=max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains; preload

docs.title: Rate limiting
docs.text:
IP-based rate limits are applied. Defaults:

  • General requests: 120 per minute
  • Login: 20 per 5 minutes
  • AI requests: 30 per minute
  • Uploads: 20 per minute

Adjust if needed:

RATE_LIMIT_GENERAL_PER_MINUTE=120
RATE_LIMIT_LOGIN_PER_5_MIN=20
RATE_LIMIT_AI_PER_MINUTE=30
RATE_LIMIT_UPLOAD_PER_MINUTE=20

docs.title: Upload security
docs.text:
Uploads have size limits:

  • Image uploads: 5MB (WebP conversion)
  • Material uploads: 10MB
  • Submissions: 5MB per file, 10MB total

Files are stored under /static/uploads. In production:

  • Minimize permissions on upload directories.
  • Add external storage or virus scanning if needed.

docs.title: Secret management
docs.text:
• Never commit .env files.
  • Use CI/CD secret storage (GitHub Actions Secrets, etc.).
  • Rotate production secrets regularly.

docs.title: Gemini API key handling
docs.text:
• Keys stored in the admin UI must be encrypted with ADMIN_PW.
  • The backend rejects plaintext keys.
  • GEMINI_API_KEY is used as the server default key.

docs.title: Audit logs
docs.text:
Important events are stored in the audit_logs table.

  • Login, settings changes, uploads, AI requests, and more
  • In production, review logs and define a retention policy

docs.title: Data protection and backups
docs.text:
• Restrict permissions on SQLite database files.
  • Use Docker volumes to avoid data loss.
  • Perform regular backups and verify restore procedures.

docs.title: Public exposure notes
docs.text:
• For public access, use ./run-public.sh --ngrok|--bore|--cloudflare.
  • Add Basic Auth if you need extra protection.

docs.title: Related docs
docs.text:
• Environment variables
  • Public deployment
  • API Reference

https://your-domain.com/api

docs.title: Authentication and sessions
docs.text:
• On login/registration, session cookie (oc_session) and CSRF cookie (oc_csrf) are issued.
  • With a session cookie, POST/PUT/DELETE requests must include the oc_csrf value in the X-CSRF-Token header.

  [
    {
      "id": "step_xxx",
      "codelab_id": "codelab_xxx",
      "step_number": 1,
      "title": "Project setup",
      "content_markdown": "# Project Setup\n\n..."
    }
  ]
]

docs.title: Get inline comments
docs.text:
GET /codelabs/:id/inline-comments

Optional query params:

  • target_type: step or guide
  • target_step_id: step ID when target_type=step

Response (200 OK): 

[
  {
    "id": "thread_xxx",
    "codelab_id": "codelab_xxx",
    "anchor_key": "step|step_xxx|hash|12|34",
    "target_type": "step",
    "target_step_id": "step_xxx",
    "start_offset": 12,
    "end_offset": 34,
    "selected_text": "Selected text",
    "content_hash": "abc123",
    "created_by_attendee_id": "attendee_xxx",
    "created_at": "2026-02-13T10:20:00Z",
    "messages": [
      {
        "id": "comment_xxx",
        "thread_id": "thread_xxx",
        "codelab_id": "codelab_xxx",
        "author_role": "attendee",
        "author_id": "attendee_xxx",
        "author_name": "Jane Doe",
        "message": "This part is confusing.",
        "created_at": "2026-02-13T10:20:00Z"
      }
    ]
  }
]

docs.title: Create inline comment
docs.text:
POST /codelabs/:id/inline-comments

Request Body: 

{
  "anchor_key": "step|step_xxx|hash|12|34",
  "target_type": "step",
  "target_step_id": "step_xxx",
  "start_offset": 12,
  "end_offset": 34,
  "selected_text": "Selected text",
  "content_hash": "abc123",
  "message": "This part is confusing."
}

If the same anchor_key already exists, the server appends a message to the existing thread. Overlapping different ranges return 400.

docs.title: Reply to inline comment
docs.text:
POST /codelabs/:id/inline-comments/:thread_id/comments

Request Body: 

{
  "message": "You can read this concept first.",
  "content_hash": "abc123"
}

If content_hash differs from the current content, the thread is treated as stale and the server returns 400.

docs.title: Delete inline comment
docs.text:
DELETE /codelabs/:id/inline-comments/:thread_id/comments/:comment_id

  • Backend mode: author or admin can delete
  • Serverless mode (Supabase/Firebase): author only

When the last message in a thread is deleted, the thread is deleted too.
